questions.name: No return statement
questions.q: If a return statment is not present in a function body, what does it return if called?

a.note: If you omit the return statement, undefined is returned implicitly.

questions.name: way to create a function
questions.q: Provide different ways of creating a function.

a.note: In JavaScript, you can create functions in several ways.
code: var foo = function(x, y){return x + y;}
var foo = new Function('x', 'y', 'return x + y;');

questions.name: function expression vs. function declaration
questions.q: What is the difference between function expressions and function declarations?

a.note: Function declarations have names and are hoisted. Function expressions can exist anywhere where a valid expression can exist. Function expressions do not require a name.
code: // Another way to create a function is by writing a function expression.
// Note that it is called an expression since it evaluates to a value.

a.note: When writing a function expression, you may assign a name to the function. This is helpful in debugging as well as it allows your function to be called recursively.
code: // Note, that this name can only be used within the function body.
▶ Uncaught ReferenceError: foo is not defined

questions.name: arrow function benefits
questions.q: What are the benefits of arrow functions?

a.note: Firstly, arrow functions are less verbose than function expressions.
Second, within arrow functions, their `this` variable is lexically bound. It isn’t necessary to create a temporary `that` variable.
code: // `this` is the the global object / undefined in strict mode

questions.name: when to avoid arrow functions
questions.q: When should arrow functions be avoided?

a.note: Arrow functions are perfect for short functions, one-liners. The longer the function, the less arrow functions help.

questions.name: invalid places for arrow functions
questions.q: In what situations can you not use arrow functions?

a.note: You cannot use arrow functions as constructor functions.
code: new Person; // TypeError: Person is not a constructor

questions.name: Way to create empty array
questions.q: List 5 ways to instantiate an empty array

code: new Array(0);   // explicit size of zero
new Array();    // implicit size of zero
new Array;      // we can omit parenthesies

questions.q: Is it possible to create an object without a prototype?

a.note: Yes. Using the Object object, you can call create() and pass in null

questions.q: If calling a constructor function, are parentheses still required?

a.note: No. You may omit the parentheses if no arguments are passed into a constructor function.
Also, you may optionally omit 'new', in which case you need to use parentheses
